solution_en: Check and adjust the lighting, acoustics, staging, etc. of the venue to work best for your presentation. If necessary, change parts of your presentation to accommodate any difficulties. If possible, rehearse your presentation at the venue to double check for any hidden problems.
consequence_en: A careful check of the stage prevents many problems, and allows your audience to concentrate on your presentation. You will also have fewer worries when speaking.

summary_ja: 成功のイメージを抱き続けるために、絶えず思い起こす。
context_ja: 「成功のイメージ」（No.3）を念頭に、準備の詰めを行っている。
b_problem_ja: いつの間にか成功のイメージを忘れてしまい、ブレてしまう。
b_solution_ja: 成功のイメージを何度も言語化・可視化して、記憶をリフレッシュする。
consequence_ja: 「成功のイメージ」（No.3）を思い出すことで、今できていることとできていないことが明確になり、これから何をしなければならないかがわかる。また、完成形が見えることで、詰めの作業へのモチベーションが上がる。
summary_en: Never forget your goal.
context_en: You are imagining your Image of Success (3) while putting the final touches to your presentation.
b_problem_en: You notice you are heading in a different direction from your original goal.
problem_en: \n• People tend to forget as time passes by.\n• If goals become unclear, so are the results.
b_solution_en: Frequently remind yourself of your Image of Success (3), whether verbally or visually, to refresh your mind.
solution_en: Talk to your teammates about the Image of Success (3) or print it out and place it where you can see it. Repetitive verbalization and visualization is what is important.
consequence_en: By reminding yourself of your goals, you can distinguish between what you've accomplished and what you still need to work on. The image of the finished work motivates you to work harder.

summary_ja: 自信は自然に湧いてくるものではない。
context_ja: 「成功のイメージ」（No.3）を念頭に、準備の詰めを行っている。
b_problem_ja: 一生懸命準備してきたはずなのに、プレゼンテーションに自信が持てない。
b_solution_ja: これまで自分がやってきたこと・こだわってきたことを１つ１つ確認し、それらを積み上げて、自信につなげる。
consequence_ja: 自信を持ってプレゼンテーションに臨むことができる。自信にあふれるプレゼンテーションは説得力を持ち、聞き手の心に響くだろう。
summary_en: Self-confidence is never spontaneous.
context_en: You are imagining your Image of Success (3) while putting the final touches to your presentation.
b_problem_en: Despite the effort you’ve put in, you don’t have much confidence in your presentation.
problem_en: \n• You don’t know what’s going to happen on stage.\n• Practice doesn’t necessary lead to self-confidence.
b_solution_en: Remind yourself of all the time and effort you have put into this presentation, stack them up and build your self-confidence.
solution_en: Remember each and every thing you have done for the presentation. Each one may be a small thing, but when put all together, they should stack up to become a mountain. Recognize how much you’ve done, and have pride in your work.
consequence_en: You give a presentation full of pride and confidence that speaks to the hearts of the listeners.

summary_ja: 立ち振る舞いもプレゼンテーションの一部である。
context_ja: いよいよプレゼンテーションの本番になり、「成功のイメージ」（No.3）が現実になろうとしている。
b_problem_ja: プレゼンテーションの内容を伝えることに集中してしまい、自分が見られているということを忘れてしまう。
b_solution_ja: 自分自身もプレゼンテーションの一部であることを意識して振る舞う。
consequence_ja: 聞き手がプレゼンテーションに惹き込まれやすくなり、内容をより力強くさせることができる。また、常に聞き手からの視線を意識することで、聞き手に目を向けたプレゼンテーションを行うことができる。
summary_en: You are part of your presentation.
context_en: You are minutes away from the stage and your Image of Success (3) is about to come true.
b_problem_en: You become too busy trying to speak and forget that your audience is watching you.
problem_en: \n• The presentation is not the only thing that your audience sees.\n• People tend to disregard their surroundings when they have stage freight.
b_solution_en: Act as if you are part of the presentation.
solution_en: You may be busy trying to get your ideas across, but your audience is also looking at your body language. Untidy clothes or careless body actions give a bad impression. Keep in mind that your presentation begins the moment you walk on stage, and ends when you walk off.
consequence_en: On feeling the gaze of your audience, you can give a presentation made especially for them. This helps engage your audience.

summary_ja: 余計な言い訳はいらない。今できるベストを尽くす。
context_ja: いよいよプレゼンテーションの本番になり、「成功のイメージ」（No.3）が現実になろうとしている。
b_problem_ja: 自分が自信を持っていない部分について言い訳をしてしまうことで、自らプレゼンテーションの価値を下げてしまう。
b_solution_ja: 言い訳はせず、今できるベストを尽くす。
consequence_ja: 聞き手は、言い訳しなければならないようなネガティブな点に意識がいくのではなく、プレゼンテーションの良い点をみることになり、魅力的なプレゼンテーションが成立する。
summary_en: No excuses.
context_en: You are minutes away from the stage and your Image of Success (3) is about to come true.
b_problem_en: You make excuses about the parts you are less confident in, which makes the presentation worse.
problem_en: \n• You make excuses to buy sympathy from your audience.\n• No one likes to hear other people make excuses.
b_solution_en: Make no excuses and give the best presentation you can at that time.
solution_en: Recall your Main Message (1), and think of how you can make it into a Touching Gift (2). At this point of the preparation stage, all other details are small things you don’t need to worry about. Just give the best presentation you can.
consequence_en: Your audience is less likely to notice the poorer parts of your presentation if you don’t point them out by making excuses. Instead, they would find your presentation appealing by noticing the good parts.

summary_ja: 聞き手の目を見て伝える想い。
context_ja: いよいよプレゼンテーションの本番になり、「成功のイメージ」（No.3）が現実になろうとしている。
b_problem_ja: つくってきた内容を話すことに必死になり、聞き手に伝えようとする姿勢がおろそかになる。
b_solution_ja: 聞き手１人１人に伝えようとする姿勢で、意識的に聞き手の目を見ながら発表を行う。
consequence_ja: 聞き手は、自分に語りかけられているという感覚を抱き、より熱心にプレゼンテーションを聞くようになる。また、話し手は、聞き手の反応を感じることができるため、安心感と喜びを感じることができる。これらは効果を高め合い、相乗効果を生む。
summary_en: For each and every one.
context_en: You are minutes away from the stage and your Image of Success (3) is about to come true.
b_problem_en: Your attitude towards your audience becomes careless in the rush to get your idea across.
problem_en:
• People tend to disregard their surroundings when they have stage freight.
• You become unsure where to look when you are in front of an audience all staring at you.
• Words won’t reach your audience if you are staring off into space.
b_solution_en: Intentionally make eye contact with your audience in an effort to give the presentation to each and every one of them.
solution_en: Don’t just look anywhere when speaking. Make the effort to make eye contact with each person in your audience. While doing so, check their expressions and reactions to ensure they are following you. If you feel they are not following you, change the speed or tone of your presentation.
consequence_en: The audience feels you are speaking to them personally, and listen more carefully. You can make sure your audience is following you, and can judge their reactions. These two effects become synergistic, leading to warm mutual feelings.

summary_ja: 徹底した世界観が聞き手の感動を生む。
context_ja: 高度な「成功のイメージ」（No.3）のプレゼンテーションを行いたい。
b_problem_ja: 表現のテクニックを磨いても、感動の度合いが上がらない。
b_solution_ja: 聞き手が惹き付けられるような魅力的な“世界”を垣間見せ、そこに導く。
consequence_ja: 聞き手が「もっとこの“世界”を味わいたい」と思うような魅力的なプレゼンテーションとなる。作り手自身も、その“世界”に入り込むことで、自ら楽しみながらプレゼンテーションを行うことができる。
summary_en: Invite them to a whole new world.
context_en: You want to give a presentation with a high level Image of Success (3).
b_problem_en: You are brushing up your expressions, but you feel your presentation isn’t improving much.
problem_en: \n• Good impressions don’t necessary come just from the words that are used.\n• There are many people who can use attractive words in their speeches.
b_solution_en: Have an alluring “world” in your presentation, let your audience glimpse that “world,” and then guide them into it.
solution_en: First think about what kind of an atmosphere would attract your audience. Once you find it, make every aspect of your presentation fit this atmosphere. Then, be the first person to jump into this “world,” and invite your audience in.
consequence_en: Your presentation create a “world” your audience wants to jump into. You too can have fun creating your “world” and speaking about it. See also Collaboration Patterns, another volume of this catalogue series, for patterns for creating a new world.

summary_ja: 「即興」と「行き当たりばったり」は、まったく違う。
context_ja: 高度な「成功のイメージ」（No.3）のプレゼンテーションを行いたい。
b_problem_ja: 相手の反応に合わせた進行にしようとすると、うまくまとまらないことがある。
b_solution_ja: 日頃から即興のためのレパートリーを充実させておき、本番でそれらを即興的に選びながらプレゼンテーションを行う。
consequence_ja: 聞き手の反応に合わせてプレゼンテーションをすることで、聞き手の興味をそそる内容となり、聞き手の反応もよくなり、会場の雰囲気自体がよくなる。また、話す前に自分の話の要点や構成をより明確に把握できる。
summary_en: The plan to have no plans.
context_en: You want to give a presentation with a high level Image of Success (3).
b_problem_en: You find yourself having trouble progressing in your presentation because of the audience reactions.
problem_en:
• You never know how your audience will react to your presentation beforehand.
• You won’t know what to do when something unexpected happens.
• A good presentation is never made from having no plans on what to do.
b_solution_en: Have a repertoire of speeches you can put together and improvise based on the audience reactions.
solution_en: Memorize multiple patterns of speeches that can accommodate many situations, and use them as the need arises when presenting.
consequence_en: You present based on your audience's interests, creating a warm environment for you and your audience. Also, as the final presentation script the speech is not planned, you need to understand the key points of your presentation very well.

summary_ja: 振り返りまでがプレゼンテーション。
context_ja: 高度な「成功のイメージ」（No.3）のプレゼンテーションを行いたい。
b_problem_ja: 本番が終わったことで解放感に浸り、やりっ放しになってしまう。
b_solution_ja: 本番中の自らの振る舞いや聞き手の反応から、今回のプレゼンテーション全体を振り返る。
consequence_ja: 次回のプレゼンテーションの準備や発表の仕方が改善される。また、プレゼンテーションをただやりっ放しにするのではなく、1回1回の経験と反省を積み重ねることで、作り手のなかにプレゼンテーションのノウハウが蓄積されていく。
summary_en: Reflections are still part of your presentation.
context_en: You want to give a presentation with a high level Image of Success (3).
b_problem_en: You feel satisfied when you finish speaking, and take no action afterwards.
problem_en: \n• You are just happy your presentation has ended, and satisfaction arises.\n• Your memory of your presentation diminishes as time passes.
b_solution_en: Evaluate your presentation through self-reflection and the reaction of others.
solution_en: Keep a record of your self-reflection and the audience comments after your presentation. Note both the good and bad parts of your performance. Think about how you can fix the bad parts and make the good parts even better for your future presentations.
consequence_en: By reflecting upon your performance each time, you take full advantage of your presenting experience, and your presentations get better every time.

summary_ja: 自分なりの山をつくりながら、高みを目指す。
context_ja: 「創造的プレゼンテーション」（No.0）を極めたい。
b_problem_ja: 他の人と同じようなプレゼンテーションになってしまう。
b_solution_ja: 内容・表現ともに自分らしさを追求し、他の人との差異も意識し、独自性をつくっていく。
consequence_ja: 聞き手は、自分にも他の人にもない独自性のあるプレゼンテーションを味わうことができる。また、作り手は独自性を追求するプロセスのなかで、自分と深く向き合い、自分のなかに新しい価値や可能性を見出したり、構築したりする機会になる。
summary_en: Head for a presentation that only you can give.
context_en: You want to give a truly Creative Presentation (0).
b_problem_en: Your presentations are somewhat similar to other people’s presentations.
problem_en: \n• Originality doesn’t come spontaneously, nor can it be learned from someone else.\n• It’s no fun just mimicking what other people are doing.
b_solution_en: Be aware of your differences and pursue originality.
solution_en: Ask what defines you as you. No one else in the world has the same experiences as you, and there are things only you understand. From those things, your originality can be found.
consequence_en: Your audience experiences a presentation they have never seen before. Through the presentation preparation process, you have a chance to deeply reflect upon yourself, creating new possibilities or values. See also Learning Patterns, another volume of this catalogue series, for patterns for learning by creating.

summary_ja: 自分なりの魅せ方を日々探求し、磨いていく。
context_ja: 「創造的プレゼンテーション」（No.0）を極めたい。
b_problem_ja: 同じ表現を繰り返してしまい、どれも似たようなプレゼンテーションになってしまう。
b_solution_ja: 魅せ方についての感覚を日々探求し、自分なりの「魅せ方の美学」を持つ。
consequence_ja: 自分のプレゼンテーションを何度も聞いている聞き手に対しても、いつも発見やワクワク感のあるプレゼンテーションをすることができる。また、ふだんから探求することによって、表現することに対してプライドを持つことができる。
summary_en: Polishing your senses.
context_en: You want to give a truly Creative Presentation (0).
b_problem_en: Your presentations all seem the same.
problem_en: \n• You feel that the way you know is the best way.\n• Hesitations arise when you want to change to a new way.
b_solution_en: Continue your pursuit of beauty in your presentations, and build your own esthetic values.
solution_en: Reference other people’s works you think are beautiful, take in and polish what you think you can use, and build an original sense of beauty. Give presentations based on this, and continue polishing your senses.
consequence_en: By having something new and different every time, you can amuse not just first-time listeners but also people who have listened to you speak before. Also, by having your own esthetic values, you can have pride in your work.

summary_ja: 自分の枠を大きく超えたプレゼンテーションなどできない。
context_ja: 「創造的プレゼンテーション」（No.0）を極めたい。
b_problem_ja: プレゼンテーションで、スケール感や深みをなかなか出すことができない。
b_solution_ja: 自分なりの「生き方」を編み出しながら、本気で生きる。
summary_en: Your presentations can only be as good as you are.
context_en: You want to give a truly Creative Presentation (0).
b_problem_en: You feel your presentations lack some depth and quality.
problem_en: \n• Words are only a part of your presentation.\n• The depth and quality of a presentation cannot be intentionally made.
b_solution_en: Be authentic! Live your way of Life.
solution_en: Your presentation is a mini scale model of your life, in which your experiences, way of life, and emotions are all condensed. Only a person living authentically can deliver a presentation that truly touches and moves the audience. So live to your full potential and create your own way of life.
